display_asset.caption: Bobby Ray Simmons Jr., better known as B.o.B.

summaries.body: The rapper B.o.B, insisting that the earth is flat, released a “diss track” aimed at the astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson after the two argued on Twitter.
If your U.S. passport is expiring this year, you should renew it now. State Department officials expect a flood of renewals of 10-year passports issued in 2006 and 2007.

display_asset.caption: Apartments sit on the edge of an eroding coastal bluff in Pacifica, Calif.

summaries.body: Apartments atop a cliff near San Francisco are dangerously close to falling into the Pacific Ocean after powerful waves and heavy rains accelerated the erosion of bluffs.
"The Tale of Kitty-In-Boots," a previously unpublished story by the author Beatrix Potter, features an older version of Peter Rabbit.
Ten police officers in Afghanistan were poisoned by a rogue officer and then shot in the head by Taliban fighters the officer was working with, an official said.

display_asset.caption: When Scott M. Stringer, the New York City comptroller, took office in early 2014, he said it was apparent then that aspects of the retirement system were “hanging by a thread.”

summaries.body: New York City’s pension system is vulnerable to an “operational failure,” according to an independent report commissioned by the city comptroller’s office.
Christie’s on Tuesday announced total sales of $7.4 billion for 2015, down 5 percent over the same period the previous year.
The former Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld has added a new line to his résumé: app developer.
Woody Allen has cast Miley Cyrus alongside himself in his coming streaming series for Amazon. The untitled project, which is set in the 1960s, will also star Elaine May.
A critic calls Trevor Noah’s “Daily Show” irrelevant to the 2016 election, something that she says was unimaginable during the Jon Stewart years.

display_asset.caption: The long-tailed macaque is one species used in a study of autism that could help find therapies for the syndrome in humans.

summaries.body: Scientists in Shanghai are trying to locate the deficiency in the "brain circuits" responsible for autism-like behavior found in genetically engineered monkeys.

display_asset.caption: The Law Barracks at the Citadel in Charleston, S.C., in 2007.

summaries.body: Fourteen cadets at the Citadel in Charleston, S.C., were disciplined for dressing up last month in costumes evoking the Ku Klux Klan.

display_asset.caption: Black ants, with a bit of food on a couch, are among the hundreds of arthropods that make their way into American homes, a study found.

summaries.body: An unusual survey identifies many of the bugs living with us in our houses. (Hint: There are probably more than 100 species in yours.)

display_asset.caption: Mike Piazza with the Mets in 2005. Piazza, a newly elected Hall of Famer, will have his No. 31 retired during a ceremony at Citi Field on July 30.

summaries.body: The Mets will retire Mike Piazza’s No. 31. Piazza, recently voted into the Baseball Hall of Fame, will become only the fourth team member to have his number retired.
A University of Missouri professor who called for "some muscle" to remove journalists from a campus protest was charged with misdemeanor assault.

display_asset.credit: Orange County Sheriff's Office, via Associated Press

summaries.body: Investigators shared photos depicting how they think three inmates may have escaped from a maximum-security jail in Santa Ana, Calif.
Dov Charney, the ousted founder of American Apparel, lost a bid to return to the company when a Delaware Bankruptcy Court judge ruled against him.
A 6.3-magnitude earthquake struck in the Mediterranean early on Monday, causing damage in Spain and Morocco, although no deaths or injuries were reported.

display_asset.caption: The police said that the man, who was in his 20s, had confronted the woman in the building where they both lived, in what appeared to be an unprovoked attack.
display_asset.credit: Edwin J. Torres for The New York Times

summaries.body: A 59-year-old woman in the Bronx was fatally attacked by a neighbor wielding a machete on Sunday afternoon, the police said.
The writer Ta-Nehisi Coates criticizes Senator Bernie Sanders for calling himself a "radical," writing that there is dissonance between the title and the senator's approach.

display_asset.caption: Benjamin Amsellem survived an attack by using his Torah.

summaries.body: In Marseille, France, there have been three attacks on Jews since October, elevating concerns about a new strain of ISIS-related anti-Semitism.

display_asset.caption: Jack Dorsey, who was named Twitter’s permanent chief in October, has not been shy about making personnel changes.

summaries.body: Twitter is said to be undergoing a major overhaul of its top ranks in the next few weeks, from its eight-member board to key executives in engineering and product.

display_asset.caption: A forged painting sold as an untitled Rothko from 1956.

summaries.body: A lawsuit involving the 2004 purchase of a fake Rothko begins Monday in Manhattan, the first trial to result from the sale of more than 30 forgeries by the Knoedler gallery.
A man accused of accidentally shooting a stranger at a theater in Washington State says he was armed because he was worried about mass shootings, the police said.

display_asset.caption: LaVoy Finicum at the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge near Burns, Ore., last week.

summaries.body: As the three-week standoff at an Oregon wildlife refuge continues, occupiers and federal officials have taken their quarrel over Native American artifacts to social media.

display_asset.credit: Credit New York Police Department 103rd Precinct

summaries.body: A cow that escaped from a slaughterhouse and briefly roamed through Queens on Thursday will get to live at a New Jersey sanctuary under the name Freddie Mercury.

Federal officials updated the list of places that pregnant women should avoid because of the risk of the Zika virus to include Barbados, Bolivia, Ecuador, Guadeloupe, St. Martin, Guyana, Samoa and Cape Verde.

display_asset.caption: Vonn is one win away from surpassing Annemarie Moser-Pröll’s record as the most decorated downhill racer in World Cup history.

summaries.body: With a victory Saturday in Cortina d'Ampezzo, Italy, Lindsey Vonn would become the most decorated downhill racer in World Cup history, male or female, with 37 career wins.

display_asset.caption: A welcome sign on the village green of Whitesboro, N.Y.

summaries.body: Officials of the Village of Whitesboro in upstate New York said they had agreed to replace their official seal, which depicts a white man grappling with a Native American.

display_asset.caption: The newly installed replicas of the north doors at the Bapistery in Florence, Italy.

summaries.body: After centuries exposed to the elements, the north doors of the Baptistery in Florence, bearing Lorenzo Ghiberti's gilded bronze panels, have been replaced with replicas.
